text: WITH constant succours, fain thyself to share it, make this oblation which we bring effective. Grown great through strengthening gifts at each libation, he hath become renowned by mighty exploits.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra were the Somas erst- discovered, whereby he grew strong-jointed, vast, and skilful. Indra , take quickly these presented juices: drink of the strong, that which the strong have shaken.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink and wax great. Thine are the juices, Indra, both Somas of old time and these we bring thee. Even as thou drankest, Indra, earlier Somas, so drink to-day, a new guest, meet for praises.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great and impetuous, mighty-voiced in battle, surpassing power is his, and strength resistless. Him the broad earth hath never comprehended when Somas cheered the Lord of Tawny Coursers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty and strong he waxed for hero exploit: the Bull was furnished a Sage's wisdom. Indra is our kind Lord; his steers have vigour; his cows are many with abundant offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As floods according to their stream flow onward, so to the sea, as borne on cars, the waters. Vaster is Indra even than his dwelling, what time the stalk milked out, the Soma, fills him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eager to mingle with the sea, the rivers carry the well-pressed Soma juice to Indra. They drain the stalk out with their arms, quick-banded, and cleanse it with a stream of mead and filters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like lakes appear his flanks filled full with Soma: yea, he contains libations in abundance. When Indra had consumed the first sweet viands, he, after slaying Vṛtra, claimed the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then bring thou hither, and let none prevent it: we know thee well, the Lord of wealth and treasure. That splendid gift which is thine own, O Indra, vouchsafe to us, Lord of the Tawny Coursers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Maghavan, impetuous mover, grant us abundant wealth that brings all blessings. Give us a hundred autumns for our lifetime: give us, O fair-checked Indra, store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Indra, Maghavan, auspicious, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered, The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O INDRA, for the strength that slays Vṛtra and conquers in the fight, We turn thee hitherward to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers, may those who praise thee hitherward. Direct thy spirit and thine eye.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers, with all our songs we invocate Thy names for triumph over foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We strive for glory through the powers immense of him whom many praise, Of Indra who supports mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Vṛtra's slaughter I address Indra whom many invocate, To win us booty in the wars.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In battles be victorious. We seek thee, Lord of Hundred Powers, Indra, that Vṛtra may be slain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In splendid combats of the hosts, in glories where the fight is won. Indra, be victor over foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink thou the Soma for our help, bright, vigilant, exceeding strong, O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Śatakratu, powers which thou mid the Five Races hast displayed- These, Indra, do I claim of thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, great glory hast thou gained. Win splendid fame which none may mar We make thy might perpetual.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us either from anear, Or, Śakra, come from far away. Indra, wherever be thy home, come to us thence, O Thunder-armed. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HASTING like some strong courser good at drawing, a thought have I imagined like a workman. Pondering what is dearest and most noble, I long to see the sages full of wisdom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ask of the sages' mighty generations firm-minded and devout they framed the heaven. These are thy heart-sought strengthening directions, and they have come to be sky's upholders.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Assuming in this world mysterious natures, they decked the heaven and earth for high dominion, Measured with measures, fixed their broad expanses, set the great worlds apart held firm for safety.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as he mounted up they all adorned him: self-luminous he travels clothed in splendour. That is the Bull's, the Asura's mighty figure: he, omniform, hath reached the eternal waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: First the more ancient Bull engendered offspring; these are his many draughts that lent him vigour. From days of old ye Kings, two Sons of Heaven, by hymns of sacrifice have won dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three seats ye Sovrans, in the Holy synod, many, yea, all, ye honour with your presence. There saw I, going thither in the spirit, Gandharvas in their course with wind-blown tresses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That same companionship of her, the Milch-cow, here with the strong Bull's divers forms they stablished. Enduing still some new celestial figure, the skilful workers shaped a form around him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let no one here debar me from enjoying the golden light which Savitar diffuses. He covers both all-fostering worlds with praises even as a woman cherishes her children.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fulfil, ye twain, his work, the Great, the Ancient: as heavenly blessing keep your guard around us. All the wise Gods behold his varied actions who stands erect, whose voice is like a herdsman's.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Indra, Maghavan, auspicious, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered, The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN XXXIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra from the heart the hymn proceedeth, to him the Lord, recited, built with praises; The wakening song sung forth in holy synod: that which is born for thee, O Indra, notice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born from the heaven e’en in the days aforetime, wakening, sting aloud in holy synod, Auspicious, clad in white and shining raiment, this is the ancient hymn of our forefathers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Mother of the Twins hath borne Twin Children: my tongue's tip raised itself and rested silent. Killing the darkness at the light's foundation, the Couple newly born attain their beauty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not one is found among them, none of mortals, to blame our sires who fought to win the cattle. Their strengthener was Indra the Majestic he spread their stalls of kine the Wonder-Worker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where as a Friend with friendly men, Navagvas, with heroes, on his knees he sought the cattle. There, verily with ten Daśagvas Indra found the Sun lying hidden in the darkness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra found meath collected in the milch-cow, by foot and hoof, in the cow's place of pasture. That which lay secret, hidden in the waters, he held in his right hand, the rich rewarder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He took the light, discerning it from darkness: may we be far removed from all misfortune. These songs, O Soma-drinker, cheered by Soma, Indra, accept from thy most zealous poet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let there be light through both the worlds for worship: may we be far from most overwhelming evil. Great woe comes even from the hostile mortal, piled up; but good at rescue are the Vasus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Maghavan, auspicious Indra, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered, The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN XL. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEE, Indra, we invoke, the Bull, what time the Soma is expressed. So drink thou of the savoury juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, whom many laud, accept the strength-conferring Soma juice: Quaff, pour down drink that satisfies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, with all the Gods promote our wealth-bestowing sacrifice, Thou highly-lauded Lord of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the brave, to thee proceed these drops of Soma juice expressed, The bright drops to thy dwelling-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Within thy belly, Indra, take juice, Soma the most excellent: Thine are the drops celestial.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink our libation, Lord of hymns: with streams of meath thou art bedewed Our glory, Indra, is thy gift.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra go the treasures of the worshipper, which never fail: He drinks the Soma and is strong

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From far away, from near at hand, O Vṛtra-slayer, come to us: Accept the songs we sing to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When from the space between the near and far thou art invoked by us, Thence, Indra. come thou hitherward. Next: HYMN XLI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INVOKED to drink the Soma juice, come with thy Bay Steeds, Thunder-armed Come, Indra, hitherward to me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our priest is seated, true to time; the grass is regularly strewn; The pressing-stones were set at morn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These prayers, O thou who hearest prayer are offered: seat thee on the grass. Hero, enjoy the offered cake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vṛtra-slayer, be thou pleased with these libations, with these hymns, Song-loving Indra, with our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our hymns caress the Lord of Strength, vast, drinker of the Soma's juice, Indra, as mother-cows their calf.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Delight thee with the juice we pour for thine own great munificence: Yield not thy singer to reproach.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We, Indra, dearly loving thee, bearing oblation, sing thee hymns Thou, Vasu, dearly lovest us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou to whom thy Bays are dear, loose not thy Horses far from us: Here glad thee, Indra, Lord divine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May long-maned Coursers, dropping oil, bring thee on swift car hitherward, Indra, to seat thee on the grass. Next: HYMN XLII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME to the juice that we have pressed, to Soma, Indra, bleat with milk: Come, favouring us, thy Bay-drawn car!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Indra, to this gladdening drink, placed on the grass, pressed out with stones: Wilt thou not drink thy fill thereof?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra have my songs of praise gone forth, thus rapidly sent hence, To turn him to the Soma-draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither with songs of praise we call Indra to drink the Soma juice: Will he not come to us by lauds?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, these Somas are expressed. Take them within thy belly, Lord Of Hundred Powers, thou Prince of Wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We know thee winner of the spoil, and resolute in battles, Sage! Therefore thy blessing we implore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne hither by thy Stallions, drink, Indra, this juice which we have pressed, Mingled with barley and with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, for thee, in thine own place, I urge the Soma for thy draught: Deep in thy heart let it remain,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call on thee, the Ancient One, Indra, to drink the Soma juice, We Kuśikas who seek thine aid. Next: HYMN XLIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MOUNTED upon thy chariot-seat approach us: thine is the Soma-draught from days aforetime. Loose for the sacred grass thy dear companions. These men who bring oblation call thee hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come our true Friend, passing by many people; come with thy two Bay Steeds to our devotions; For these our hymns are calling thee, O Indra, hymns formed for praise, soliciting thy friendship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pleased, with thy Bay Steeds, Indra, God, come quickly to this our sacrifice that heightens worship; For with my thoughts, presenting oil to feed thee, I call thee to the feast of sweet libations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, let thy two Bay Stallions bear thee hither, well limbed and good to draw, thy dear companions. Pleased with the corn-blent offering which we bring thee, may Indra, Friend, hear his friend's adoration.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wilt thou not make me guardian of the people, make me, impetuous Maghavan, their ruler? Make me a Ṛṣi having drunk of Soma? Wilt thou not give me wealth that lasts for ever?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yoked to thy chariot, led thy tall Bays, Indra, companions of thy banquet, bear thee hither, Who from of old press to heaven's farthest limits, the Bull's impetuous and well-groomed Horses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink of the strong pressed out by strong ones, Indra, that which the Falcon brought thee when thou longedst; In whose wild joy thou stirrest up the people, in whose wild joy thou didst unbar the cow-stalls.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Indra, Makhavan, auspicious, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered; The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN XLIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this delightsome Soma be expressed for thee by tawny stones. Joying thereat, O Indra, with thy Bay Steeds come:. ascend thy golden-coloured car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In love thou madest Uṣas glow, in love thou madest Sūrya shine. Thou, Indra, knowing, thinking, Lord of Tawny Steeds, above all glories waxest great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The heaven with streams of golden hue, earth with her tints of green and gold- The golden Pair yield Indra plenteous nourishment: between them moves the golden One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When born to life the golden Bull illumines all the realm of light. He takes his golden weapon, Lord of Tawny Steeds, the golden thunder in his arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The bright, the well-loved thunderbolt, girt with the bright, Indra disclosed, Disclosed the Soma juice pressed out by tawny stones, with tawny steeds drave forth the kine. Next: HYMN XLV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME hither, Indra, with Bay Steeds, joyous, with tails like peacocks' plumes. Let no men cheek thy course as fowlers stay the bird: pass o’er them as o’er desert lands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who slew Vṛtra, burst the cloud, brake the strongholds and drave the floods, Indra who mounts his chariot at his Bay Steeds' cry, shatters e’en things that stand most firm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like pools of water deep and full, like kine thou cherishest thy might; Like the milch-cows that go well-guarded to the mead, like water-brooks that reach the lake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring thou us wealth with power to strike, our share, 'gainst him who calls it his. Shake, Indra, as with hooks, the tree for ripened fruit, for wealth to satisfy our wish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, self-ruling Lord art thou, good Leader, of most glorious fame. So, waxen in thy strength, O thou whom many praise, be thou most swift to hear our call. Next: HYMN XLVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: OF thee, the Bull, the Warrior, Sovran Ruler, joyous and fierce, ancient and ever youthful, The undecaying One who wields the thunder, renowned and great, great are the exploits, Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great art thou, Mighty Lord, through manly vigour, O fierce One, gathering spoil, subduing others, Thyself alone the universe's Sovran: so send forth men to combat and to rest them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath surpassed all measure in his brightness, yea, and the Gods, for none may be his equal. Impetuous Indra in his might cxccedcth wide vast mid-air and heaven and earth together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra, even as rivers to the ocean, flow forth from days of old the Soma juices; To him wide deep and mighty from his birth-time, the well of holy thoughts, aIl-comprehending.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma, Indra, which the earth and heaven bear for thee as a mother bears her infant, This they send forth to thee, this, vigorous Hero! Adhvaryus purify for thee to drink of. Next: HYMN XLVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DRINK, Indra, Marut-girt, as Bull, the Soma, for joy, for rapture even as thou listest. Pour down the flood of meath within thy belly: thou from of old art King of Soma juices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, accordant, with the banded Maruts, drink Soma, Hero, as wise Vṛtra-slayer. Slay thou our foemen, drive away assailants and make us safe on every side from danger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, drinker at due seasons, drink in season, Indra, with friendly Gods, our pressed-out Soma. The Maruts following, whom thou madest sharers, gave thee the victory, and thou slewest Vṛtra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink Soma, Indra, banded with the Maruts who, Maghavan, strengthened thee at Ahi's slaughter, 'Gainst Śambara, Lord of Bays! in winning cattle, and now rejoice in thee, the holy Singers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull whose strength hath waxed, whom Maruts follow, free-giving Indra, the celestial Ruler, Mighty, all-conquering, the victory-giver, him let us call to grant us new protection. Next: HYMN XLVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SOON as the young Bull sprang into existence he longed to taste the pressed-out Soma's liquor. Drink thou thy fill, according to thy longing, first, of the goodly mixture blent with Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That day when thou wast born thou, fain to taste it, drankest the plant's milk which the mountains nourish. That milk thy Mother first, the Dame who bare thee, poured for thee in thy mighty Father's dwelling.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Desiring food he came unto his Mother, and on her breast beheld the pungent Soma. Wise, he moved on, keeping aloof the others, and wrought great exploits in his varied aspects.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fierce, quickly conquering, of surpassing vigour, he framed his body even as he listed. E’en from his birth-time Indra conquered Tvaṣṭar, bore off the Soma and in beakers drank it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Maghavan, auspicious Indra, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered; The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN XLIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GREAT Indra will I laud, in whom all people who drink the Soma have attained their longing; Whom, passing wise, Gods, Heaven and Earth, engendered, formed by a Master's hand, to crush the Vṛtras.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, most heroic, borne by Tawny Coursers, verily none subdueth in the battle; Who, reaching far, most vigorous, hath shortened the Dasyu's life with Warriors bold of spirit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Victor in fight, swift mover like a warhorse, pervading both worlds, rainer down of blessings, To he invoked in war like Bhaga, Father, as ’twere, of hymns, fair, prompt to hear, strength-giver.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Supporting heaven, the high back of the region, his car is Vāyu with his team of Vasus. Illumining the nights, the Sun's creator, like Dhiṣaṇā he deals forth strength and riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Maghavan, auspicious Indra, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered; The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers treasure. Next: HYMN L. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET Indra drink, All-hail! for his is Soma,—the mighty Bull come, girt by Maruts, hither. Far-reaching, let him fill him with these viands, and let our offering sate his body's longing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I yoke thy pair of trusty Steeds for swiftness, whose faithful service from of old thou lovest. Here, fair of cheek! let thy Bay Coursers place thee: drink of this lovely welleffused libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With milk they made Indra their good Preserver, lauding for help and rule the bounteous rainer. Impetuous God, when thou hast drunk the Soma, enraptured send us cattle in abundance.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With kine and horses satisfy this longing with very splendid bounty still extend it. Seeking the light, with hymns to thee, O Indra, the Kuśikas have brought their gift, the singers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call we on Maghavan, auspicious Indra, best Hero in the fight where spoil is gathered; The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vṛtras, wins and gathers riches. Next: HYMN LI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HIGH hymns have sounded forth the praise of Maghavan, supporter of mankind, of Indra meet for lauds; Him who hath waxen great, invoked with beauteous songs, Immortal One, whose praise each day is sung aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra from all sides go forth my songs of praise, the Lord of Hundred Powers, strong, Hero, like the sea, Swift, winner of the booty, breaker-down of forts, faithful and ever-glorious, finder of the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where battle's spoil is piled the singer winneth praise, for Indra taketh care of matchless worshippers. He in Vivasvān's dwelling findeth his delight: praise thou the ever-conquering slayer of the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee, valorous, most heroic of the heroes, shall the priests glorify with songg and praises. Full of all wondrous power he goes to conquest: worship is his, sole Lord from days aforetime.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Abundant are the gifts he gives to mortals: for him the earth bears a rich store of treasures. The heavens, the growing plants, the living waters, the forest trees preserve their wealth for Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, O Indra, Lord of Bays, for ever are offered prayers and songs: accept them gladly. As Kinsman think thou of some fresh assistance; good Friend, give strength and life to those who praise thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Indra, drink thou Soma with the Maruts, as thou didst drink the juice beside Śāryāta. Under thy guidance, in thy keeping, Hero, the singers serve, skilled in fair sacrifices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So eagerly desirous drink the Soma, our juice, O Indra, with thy friends the Maruts, Since at thy birth all Deities adorned thee for the great fight, O thou invoked of many.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He was your comrade in your zeal, O Maruts: they, rich in noble gifts, rejoiced in Indra. With them together let the Vṛtra-slayer drink in his home the worshipper's libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Lord of affluent gifts, this juice hath been pressed for thee with strength Drink of it, thou who lovest song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Incline thy body to this juice which suits thy Godlike nature well: May it cheer thee who lovest it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brave Indra, let it work through both thy flanks, and through thy head by prayer, And through thine arms, to prosper us. Next: HYMN LII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, accept at break of day our Soma mixt with roasted corn, With groats with cake, with eulogies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept, O Indra, and enjoy the well-dressed sacrificial cake: Oblations are poured forth to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Consume our sacrificial cake, accept the songs of praise we sing, As he who woes accepts his bride.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Famed from of old, accept the cake at our libation poured at dawn, Forgreat, O Indra, is thy power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let roasted corn of our midday libation, and sacrificial cake here please thee, Indra, What time the lauding singer, keen of purpose and eager as a bull, with hymns implores thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At the third sacrifice, O thou whom many praise, give glory to the roasted corn and holy cake. With offered viands and with songs may we assist thee, Sage, whom Vāja and the Ṛbhus wait upon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The groats have we prepared for thee with Pūṣan, corn for thee, Lord of Bay Steeds, with thy horses. Eat thou the meal-cake, banded with the Maruts, wise Hero, Vṛtra-slayer, drink the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring forth the roasted corn to meet him quickly, cake for the bravest Hero mid the heroes. Indra, may hymns accordant with thee daily strengthen thee, Bold One, for the draught of Soma. Next: HYMN LIII. Indra, Parvata, Etc.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ON a high car, O Parvata and Indra, bring pleasant viands, with brave heroes, hither. Enjoy the gifts, Gods, at our sacrifices wax strong by hymns, rejoice in our oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stay still, O Maghavan, advance no farther. a draught of well-pressed Soma will I give thee. With sweetest song I grasp, O Mighty Indra, thy garment's hem as a child grasps his father's.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adhvaryu, sing we both; sing thou in answer: make we a laud acceptable to Indra. Upon this sacrificer's grass he seated: to Indra shall our eulogy be uttered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A wife, O Maghavan is home and dwelling: so let thy Bay Steeds yoked convey thee hither. Whenever we press out for thee the Soma, let Agni as our Herald speed to call thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Depart, O Maghavan;again come hither: both there and here thy goat is Indra, Brother, Where thy tall chariot hath a place to rest in, and where thqu loosest thy loud-neighing Courser.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hast drunk Soma, Indra, turn thee homeward; thy joy is in thy home, thy racious Consort; Where thy tall chariot hath a place to rest in, and thy strong Courser is set free with guerdon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bounteous are these, Aṅgirases, Virupas: the Asura's Heroes and the Sons of Heaven. They, giving store of wealth to Viśvāmitra, prolong his life through countless Soma-pressings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan weareth every shape at pleasure, effecting magic changes in his body, Holy One, drinker out of season, coming thrice, in a moment, through fit prayers, from heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mighty sage, God-born and God-incited, who looks on men, restrained the billowy river. When Viśvāmitra was Sudās's escort, then Indra through the Kuśikas grew friendly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like swans, prepare a song of praise with pressing-stones, glad in your hymns with juice poured forth in sacrifice. Ye singers, with the Gods, sages who look on men, ye Kutikas drink up the Soma's savoury meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come forward, Kuśikas, and be attentive; let loose Sudās's horse to win him riches. East, west, and north, let the King slay the foeman, then at earth's choicest place perform his worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praises to Indra have I sung, sustainer of this earth and heaven. This prayer of Viśvāmitra keeps secure the race of Bharatas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Viśvāmitras have sung forth this prayer to Indra Thunder-aimed: So let him make us prosperous.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among the Kikatas what do thy cattle? They pour no milky draught, they heat no caldron. Bring thou to us the wealth of Pramaganda;give up to us, O Maghavan, the low-born.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sasarpari, the gift of Jamadagnis, hath lowed with mighty voice dispelling famine. The Daughter of the Sun hath spread our glory among the Gods, imperishable, deathless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sasarpari brought glory speedily to these, over the generations of the Fivefold Race; Daughter of Paksa, she bestows new vital power, she whom the ancient Jamadagnis gave to me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong be the pair of oxen, firm the axles, let not the pole slip nor the yoke be broken. May Indra, keep the yoke-pins from decaying: attend us, thou whose fellies are uninjured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, give our bodies strength, strength to the bulls who draw the wains, Strength to our seed and progeny that they may live, for thou art he who giveth strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enclose thee in the heart of Khayar timber, in the car wrought of Sinsapa put firmness. Show thyself strong, O Axle, fixed and strengthened: throw us not from the car whereon we travel.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not this sovran of the wood leave us forlorn or injure us. Safe may we be until we reach our homes and rest us and unyoke.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With various aids this day come to us, Indra, with best aids speed us, Maghavan, thou Hero. Let him who hatcth us fall headlong downward: him whom we hate let vital breath abandon.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He heats his very axe, and then cuts a mere Semal blossom off. O Indra, like a caldron cracked and seething, so he pours out foam.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men notice not the arrow, O ye people; they bring the red beast deeming it a bullock. A sluggish steed men run not with the courser, nor ever lead an ass before a charger.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These men, the sons of Bhārata, O Indra, regard not severance or close connexion. They urge their own steed as it were another's, and take him, swift as the bow's string, to battle. Next: HYMN LIV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him adorable, mighty, meet for synods, this strengthening hymn, unceasing, have they offered. May Agni hear us with his homely splendours, hear us, Eternal One, with heavenly lustre.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To mighty Heaven and Earth I sing forth loudly: my wish goes out desirous and well knowing Both, at whose laud in synods, showing favour, the Gods rejoice them with the living mortal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Heaven and Earth, may your great law he faithful: he ye our leaders for our high advantage. To Heaven and Earth I offer this my homage, with food, O Agni, as I pray for riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, holy Heaven and Earth, the ancient sages whose word was ever true had power to find you; And brave men in the fightwhere heroes conquer, O Earth, have known you well and paid you honour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What pathway leadeth to the Gods? Who knoweth this of a truth, and who will now declare it? Seen are their lowest dwelling-places only, but they are in remote and secret regions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sage who looketh on mankind hath viewed them bedewed, rejoicing in the seat of Order. They make a home as for a bird, though parted, with one same will finding themselves together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Partners though parted, with far-distant limits, on one firm place both stand for ever watchful, And, being young for evermore, as sisters, speak to each other names that are united.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All living things they part and keep asunder; though bearing up the mighty Gods they reel not. One All is Lord of what is fixed and moving, that walks, that flies, this multiform creation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Afar the Ancient from of old I ponder, our kinship with our mighty Sire and Father,— Singing the praise whereof the Gods by custom stand on the spacious far-extended pathway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This laud, O Heaven and Earth, to you I utter: let the kind-hearted hear, whose tongue is Agni, Young, Sovran Rulers, Varuṇa and Mitra, the wise and very glorious Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fair-tongued Savitar, the golden-handed, comes thrice from heaven as Lord in our assembly. Bear to the Gods this song of praise, and send us, then, Savitar, complete and perfect safety.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deft worker, skiful-handed, helpful, holy, may Tvaṣṭar, God, give us these things to aid us, Take your delight, Ye Ṛbhus joined with Pūṣan: ye have prepared the rite with stones adjusted.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne on their flashing car, the spear-armed Maruts, the nimble Youths of Heaven, the Sons of Order, The Holy, and Sarasvatī, shall hear us: ye Mighty, give us wealth with noble offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Viṣṇu rich in marvels, songs And praises shall go as singers on the road of Bhaga,— The Chieftain of the Mighty Stride, whose Mothers, the many young Dames, never disregard him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, who rules through all his powers heroic, hath with his majesty filled earth and heaven. Lord of brave hosts, Fort-crusher, Vṛtra-slayer, gather thou up and bring us store of cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My Sires are the Nāsatyas, kind tokinsmen: the Aśvins' kinship is a glorious title. For ye are they who give us store of riches: ye guard your gift uncheated by the bounteous.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is, ye Wise, your great and glorious title, that all ye Deities abide in Indra. Friend, Much-invoked! art thou with thy dear Ṛbhus: fashion ye this our hymn for our advantage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aryaman, Aditi deserve our worship: the laws of Varuṇa remain unbroken. The lot of childlessness remove ye from us, and let our course be rich in kine and offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Gods’ envoy, sent to many a quarter, proclaim us sinless for our perfect safety. May Earth and Heaven, the Sun, the waters, hear us, and the wide firmament and constellations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear us the mouatains which distil the rain-drops, and, resting firm, rejoice in freshening moisture. May Aditi with the Ādityas hear us, and Maruts grant us their auspicious shelter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soft be our path for ever, well-provisioned: with pleasant meath, O Gods, the herbs besprinkle. Safe be my bliss, O Agni, in thy friendship: may I attain the seat of foodful. riches,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enjoy the offering: beam thou strength upon us; combine thou for our good all kinds of glory. Conquer in battle, Agni, all those foemen, and light us every day with loving kindness. Next: HYMN LV. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AT the first shining of the earliest Mornings, in the Cow's home was born the Great Eternal. Now shall the statutes of the Gods be valid. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion -

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the Gods here injure us, O Agni, nor Fathers of old time who know the region, Nor the sign set between two ancient dwellings. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My wishes fly abroad to many places: I glance back to the ancient sacrifices. Let us declare the truth when fire is kindled. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King Universal, born to sundry quarters, extended through the wood be lies on couches. One Mother rests: another feeds the Infant. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lodged in old plants, he grows again in younger, swiftly within the newly-born and tender. Though they are unimpregned, he makes them fruitful. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now lying far away, Child of two Mothers, he wanders unrestrained, the single youngling. These are the laws of Varuṇa and Mitra. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Child of two Mothers, Priest, sole Lord in synods, he still precedes while resting as foundation. They who speak sweetly bring him sweet addresses. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As to a friendly warrior when he battles, each thing that comes anear is seen to meet him. The hymn commingles with the cow's oblation. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deep within these the hoary envoy pierceth; mighty, he goeth to the realm of splendour, And looketh on us, clad in wondrous beauty. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Viṣṇu, the guardian, keeps the loftiest station, upholding dear, immortal dwelling-places. Agni knows well all these created beings. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye, variant Pair, have made yourselves twin beauties: one of the Twain is dark, bright shines the other; And yet these two, the dark, the red, are Sisters. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where the two Cows, the Mother and the Daughter, meet and give suck yielding their lordly nectar, I praise them at the seat of law eternal. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loud hath she lowed, licking the other's youngling. On what world hath the Milch-cow laid her udder? This Iḷā streameth with the milk of Order. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Earth weareth beauties manifold: uplifted, licking her Calf of eighteen months, she standeth. Well-skilled I seek the seat of law eternal. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Within a wondrous place the Twain are treasured: the one is manifest, the other hidden. One common pathway leads in two directions. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the milch-kine that have no calves storm downward, yielding rich nectar, streaming, unexhausted, These who are ever new and fresh and youthful. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Bull bellows in other regions, another herd receives the genial moisture; For he is Bhaga, King, the earth's Protector. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us declare the Hero's wealth in horses, O all ye folk: of this the Gods have knowledge. Sixfold they bear him, or by fives are harnessed. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tvaṣṭar the God, the omniform. Creator, begets and feeds mankind in various manner. His, verily, arc all these living creatures. Great is the Gods’ supreme dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The two great meeting Bowls hath he united: each of the Pair is laden with histreasure. The Hero is renowned for gathering riches. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, and on this our earth the All-Sustainer dwells like a King with noble friends about him. In his protection heroes rest in safety. Great is the Cods' supreme and sole dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich in their gifts for thee are herbs and waters, and earth brings all her wealth for thee, O Indra. May we as friends of thine share goodly treasures. Great is the Gods’ supreme and sole dominion. Next: HYMN LVI. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NOT men of magic skill, not men of wisdom impair the Gods’ first steadfast ordinances. Ne’er may the earth and heaven which know not malice, nor the fixed hills, be bowed by sage devices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One, moving not away, supports six burthens: the Cows proceed to him the true, the Highest. Near stand three Mighty Ones who travel swiftly: two are concealed from sight, one is apparent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull who wears all shapes, the triple-breasted, three-uddered, with a brood in many places, Ruleth majestic with his triple aspect, the Bull, the Everlasting Ones' impregner.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When nigh them, as their tracer he observed them: he called aloud the dear name of Ādityas. The Goddesses, the Waters, stayed to meet him: they who were wandering separate enclosed him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Streams! the wise Gods have thrice three habitations. Child of three Mothers, he is Lord in synods. Three are the holy Ladies of the Waters, thrice here from heaven supreme in our assembly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, O Savitar, from heaven thrice hither, three times a day, send down thy blessings daily. Send us, O Bhaga, triple wealth and treasure; cause the two worlds to prosper us, Preserver!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Savitar thrice from heaven pours down abundance, and the fair-handed Kings Varuṇa, Mitra; And spacious Heaven and Earth, yea, and the Waters, solicit wealth that Savitar may send us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three are the bright realms, best, beyond attainment, and three, the Asura's Heroes, rule as Sovrans, Holy and vigorous, never to be injured. Thrice may the Gods from heaven attend our synod. Next: HYMN LVII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MY thought with fine discernment hath discovered the Cow who wanders free without a herdsman, Her who hath straightway poured me food in plenty: Indra and Agni therefore are her praisers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Pūṣan, deft of hand and mighty, well-pleased have drained the heaven's exhaustless udder. As in this praise the Gods have all delighted, may I win blessing here from you, O Vasus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fain to lend vigour to the Bull, the siste.. with reverence recognize the germ within him. The Cows come lowing hither to the Youngling, to him endued with great and wondrous beauties.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fixing with thought, at sacrifice, the press-stones, I bid the well-formed Heaven and Earth come hither; For these thy flames, which give men boons in plenty, rise up on high, the beautiful, the holy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thy meath-sweet tongue that tastes fair viands, which among Gods is called the far-extended,— Therewith make all the Holy Odes be seated here for our help, and feed them with sweet juices.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let thy stream give us drink, O God, O Agni, wonderful and exhaustless like the rain-clouds. Thus care for us, O Vasu Jātavedas, show us thy loving-kindness, reaching all men. Next: HYMN LVIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Ancient's Milch-cow yields the things we long for: the Son of Dakṣiṇā travels between them. She with the splendid chariot brings refulgence. The praise of Uṣas hath awoke the Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They bear you hither by well-orderd statute: our sacred offerings rise as if to parents. Destroy in us the counsel of the niggard come hitherward, for we have shown you favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With lightly-rolling car and well-yoked horses hear this, the press-stone's song, ye Wonder-Workers. Have not the sages of old time, ye Aśvins, called you most prompt to come and stay misfortune?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Remember us, and come to us, for ever men, as their wont is, invocate the Aśvins. Friends as it were have offered you these juices, sweet, blent with milk at the first break of morning.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even through many regions, O ye Aśvins high praise is yours among mankind, ye Mighty- Come, helpers, on the paths which Gods have travelled: here your libations of sweet meath are ready.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ancient your home, auspicious is your friendship: Heroes, your wealth is with the house of Jahnu. Forming again with you auspicious friendship, let us rejoice with draughts of meath together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, Very Mighty ones, with Vāyu and with his steeds, one-minded, ever-youthful, Nāsatyas, joying in the third day's Soma, drink it, not hostile, Very Bounteous Givers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, to you are brought abundant viands in rivalry with sacred songs, unceasing. Sprung from high Law your car, urged on by press-stones, goes round the earth and heaven in one brief moment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, your Soma sheds delicious sweetness: drink ye thereof and come unto our dwelling. Your car, assuming many a shape, most often goes to the Soma-presser's place of meeting. Next: HYMN LIX. Mitra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MITRA, when speaking, stirreth men to labour: Mitra sustaineth both the earth and heaven. Mitra beholdeth men with eyes that close not. To Mitra bring, with holy oil, oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Foremost be he who brings thee food, O Mitra, who strives to keep thy sacred Law, Āditya. He whom thou helpest ne’er is slain or conquered, on him, from near or far, falls no affliction.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: joying in sacred food and free from sickness, with knees bent lowly on the earth's broad surface, Following closely the Āditya's statute, may we remain in Mitra's gracious favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Auspicious and adorable, this Mitra was born with fair dominion, King, Disposer. May we enjoy the grace of him the Holy, yea, rest in his propitious loving-kindness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The great Āditya, to be served with wor. ship, who stirreth men, is gracious to the singer. To Mitra, him most highly to be lauded, offer in fire oblation that he loveth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The gainful grace of Mitra,. God, supporter of the race of man, Gives splendour of most.glorious fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra whose glory spreads afar, he who in might surpasses heaven, Surpasses earth in his renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All the Five Races have repaired to Mitra, ever strong to aid, For he sustaineth all the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mitra to Gods, to living men, to him who strews the holy grass, Gives food fulfilling sacred Law. Next: HYMN LX. Ṛbhus.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HERE is your ghostly kinship, here, O Men: they came desirous to these holy rites with store of wealth, With wondrous arts, whereby, with schemes to meet each need, Ye gained, Sudhanvan's Sons! your share in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mighty powers wherewith. ye formed the chalices, the thought by which ye drew the cow from out the hide, The intellect wherewith ye wrought the two Bay Steeds,—through these, O Ṛbhus, ye attained divinity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Friendship with Indra have the Ṛbhus, fully gained: grandsons of Manu, they skilfully urged the work. Sudhanvan's Children won them everlasting life, serving with holy rites, pious with noble acts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In company with Indra come ye to the juice, then gloriously shall your wishes be fulfilled. Not to be paragoned, ye Priests, are your good deeds, nor your heroic acts, Ṛbhus, Sudhanvan's Sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, with the Ṛbhus, Mighty Ones, pour down the Soma juice effused, well-blent, from both thy hands. Maghalan, urged by song, in the drink-offerer's house rejoice thee with the Heroes, with Sudhanvan's Sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Ṛbhu near, and Vāja, Indra, here exult, with Saci, praised of many, in the juice we pour. These homes wherein we dwell have turned themselves to thee, -devotions to the Gods, as laws of men ordain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with the mighty Ṛbhus, Indra, come to us, strengthening with thy help the singer's holy praise; At hundred eager calls come to the living man, with thousand arts attend the act of sacrifice. Next: HYMN LXI. Uṣas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Uṣas, strong with strength, endowed witli knowledge, accept the singer's praise, O wealthy Lady. Thou, Goddess, ancient, young, and full of wisdom, movest, all-bounteous! as the Law ordaineth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine forth, O Morning, thou auspicious Goddess, on thy bright car awaking pleasant voices. Let docile horses of far-reaching splendour convey thee hitherward, the goldencoloured.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Morning, turning thee to every creature, standest on high as ensign of the Immortal, To one same goal ever and ever wending now, like a wheel, O newly-born, roll hi ther.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Letting her reins drop downward, Morning cometh, the wealthy Dame, the Lady of the dwelling; Bringing forth light, the Wonderful, the Blessed hath spread her from the bounds of earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither invoke the radiant Goddess Morning, and bring with reverence your hymn to praise her. She, dropping sweets, hath set in heaven her brightness, and, fair to look on, hath beamed forth her splendour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From heaven, with hymns, the Holy One was wakened: brightly to both worlds came the wealthy Lady. To Morning, Agni, when she comes refulgent, thou goest forth soliciting fair riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On Law's firm base the speeder of the Mornings, the Bull, hath entered mighty earth and heaven. Great is the power of Varuṇa and Mitra, which, bright, hath spread in every place its splendour. Next: HYMN LXII. Indra and Others.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YOUR well-known prompt activities aforetime needed no impulse from your faithful servant. Where, Indra-Varuṇa, is now that glory wherewith ye brought support to those who loved you?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This man, most diligent, seeking after riches, incessantly invokes you for your favour. Accordant, Indra-Varuṇa, with Maruts, with Heaven and Earth, hear ye mine invocation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, ours be this treasure ours be wealth, Maruts, with full store of heroes. May the Varūtrīs with their shelter aid us, and Bhāratī and Hotrā with the Mornings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be pleased! with our oblations, thou loved of all Gods, Bṛhaspati: Give wealth to him who brings thee gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At sacrifices, with your hymns worship the pure Bṛhaspati— I pray for power which none may bend—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull of men, whom none deceive, the wearer of each shape at will, Bṛhaspati Most Excellent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Divine, resplendent Pūṣan, this our newest hymn of eulogy, By us is chanted forth to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept with favour this my song, be gracious to the earnest thought, Even as a bridegroom to his bride.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he who sees all living things, see, them together at a glance,— May he, may Pūṣan be our help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we attain that excellent glory of Savitar the God: So May he stimulate our prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With understanding, earnestly, of Savitar the God we crave Our portion of prosperity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men, singers worship Savitar the God with hymn and holy rites, Urged by the impulse of their thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma who gives success goes forth, goes to the gathering place of Gods, To seat him at the seat of Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us and to our cattle may Soma give salutary food, To biped and to quadruped.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Soma, strengthening our power of life, and conquering our foes, In our assembly take his seat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Mitra-Varuṇa, sapient Pair, bedew our pasturage with oil, With meatb the regions of the air.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far-ruling, joyful when adored, ye reign through majesty of might, With pure laws everlastingly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lauded by Jamadagni's song, sit in the place of holy Law: Next: HYMN I. Agni.
